Award.AbstractNarration:
The Hawai'i Number Theory Conference (HINT 2019) will be held March 18-21, 2019 at the University of Hawai'i at Manoa in Honolulu, HI. HINT will bring together number theorists at all levels, both from within the US and internationally, for a four-day conference that includes six plenary talks by a diverse group of established mathematicians and four breakout sessions with more narrowly focused talks with ten to twenty speakers each. Immediately preceding the AMS Joint Western and Central Sectional meeting that will also take place at the University of Hawai'i at Manoa, HINT will provide opportunities for a diverse collection of number theorists to discuss recent developments, to interact, and to form new collaborations. HINT will also be a great opportunity for local number theorists at all levels to participate in a world class conference.

HINT 2019 will feature six plenary talks spanning a large expanse of number theory. The special sessions are titled Algebraic number theory and Diophantine equations, Arithmetic dynamics and geometry, Arithmetic statistics and its environs, and Modular forms, respectively. They will consist of a mix of shorter and longer talks and be directed at a more specialized audience. The broader plenary talks and the mix of topics for the more focused special sessions will allow for cross-pollination between disparate areas. The conference website is http://math.hawaii.edu/HINT2019/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hawaii Number Theory 2019 (HINT 2019) was a very successful international gathering of number theorists held from March 18 to 21, 2019, on the campus of the University of Hawaii at Mānoa. More than 150 participants from around the world met to attend talks from 54 speakers and gather informally during breaks and after-hours. The HINT 2019 website is available at http://math.hawaii.edu/HINT2019.

The conference schedule included five plenary talks and four concurrently-running special sessions: Algebraic numbers & Diophantine equations, Arithmetic geometry, Arithmetic statistics & its environs, and Modular forms & related topics. Of the 54 speakers, 38 were from US institutions, 6 from Canada, 8 from Europe, and 2 from Asia. A bit over two thirds of the remaining participants were from the US, with the rest hailing from Asia, Canada, Europe, and Oceania.

In terms of intellectual merit, the funding provided by the NSF was almost entirely used to fund (or partially fund) the travel and/or lodging expenses of 49 participants, with a focus on early-career mathematicians and those from underrepresented groups. More precisely, 19 funded participants were graduate students, 14 were at the post-doctoral stage of their career, and 4 were tenure-track professors. As part of the online conference registration, participants requesting funding were asked if they wanted to self-identify as being from an underrepresented group; of the funded participants, 17 self-identified as women and 2 as Latinx. NSF funding thus allowed us to increase the diversity of our participant pool along several axes. In addition, the special session topics were purposefully chosen to be mathematically diverse to encourage cross-pollination across different subfields of number theory.

It was our goal to foster gender diversity at the conference and we led by having three of the five plenary speakers be women. We were happy to be able to attract and fund so many women mathematicians. Another goal was to bring in junior mathematicians to help them meet some of the leaders of the field and we believe we were successful on that front as well, with the NSF funding being crucial to accomplishing this goal. These goals were part of the desired broader impacts of our grant. Another part was to provide a unique opportunity for the graduate students and faculty at UH Mānoa (as well as at the nearby community colleges and universities) to take part in a large number theory conference and meet their colleagues in person. Due to Hawaii's physical isolation, it is more expensive for local mathematicians to attend conferences elsewhere, and the NSF's funding allowed us to host a large gathering right here.

A small portion of the funding was combined with funding from the UH Mānoa Department of Mathematics to provide refreshments in the morning to encourage informal interaction between the participants to start the day, thus furthering our goal of increasing meetings between and amongst young researchers and leaders in the field.
